parameters.name: MethodName
parameters.description: Name of the application function used to open the file (see Remarks )

parameters.name: Description
parameters.description: File description displayed in the Save as type list

parameters.name: Extension
parameters.description: File name extensions separated by semicolons

parameters.name: OptionLabel
parameters.description: Label for your options button or an empty string

parameters.name: OptionMethodName
parameters.description: Name of the callback method to display a dialog box, which appears when a user clicks your options button or an empty string

title: ISldWorks.AddFileOpenItem3
description: Adds file types to the File > Open dialog box.
signature:
System.Boolean AddFileOpenItem3( 
   System.Int32
Cookie
,
   System.String
MethodName
,
   System.String
Description
,
   System.String
Extension
,
   System.String
OptionLabel
,
   System.String
OptionMethodName
)

parameters.name: MethodName
parameters.description: Name of the application function used to open the file (see Remarks )

parameters.name: Description
parameters.description: File description displayed in the Save as type list

parameters.name: Extension
parameters.description: File name extensions separated by semicolons

parameters.name: OptionLabel
parameters.description: Label for your options button or an empty string

parameters.name: OptionMethodName
parameters.description: Name of the callback method to display a dialog box, which appears when a user clicks your options button or an empty string

returns: True if the file types are added to the Save as type list, false if not
remarks:
Call this method in your add-in's ConnectToSW method.
Implement the function specified by MethodName with a string parameter that is the file name.
If your application is unloaded using an add-in, then you must remove any file types added with this method. See
ISldWorks::RemoveFileOpenItem2
.
The callback is called one time if the user:
Presses the Shift or Ctrl key and selects multiple files to open in the
File > Open
Dialog.
Drags-and-drops files into SOLIDWORKS from either File Explorer or the File Explorer tab in the TaskPane.
